body.p:
Colonial Society.— At a special
meeting of the Colonial Society, con-
vened to congratulate that distinguished
philosopher, the Baron von Humboldt,
upon his arrival in England, and to elect
him an honorary member of the Society,
the following letter was drafted by Mr.
Montgomery Martin, and transmitted
by the Committee to the Baron.

“Sir,—The committee of the Colonial So-
ciety, in conformity with a resolution unani-
mously adopted this day, beg leave to express
their gratification at your visit to this country
in the suite of your distinguished Sovereign.

“Identified as the Colonial Society is with
the extension of civilization, and the develop-
ment of the internal resources of distant and
imperfectly known foreign regions, the Society
gladly avails itself of the present opportunity to
tender its respectful congratulations to a philo-
sopher, whose invaluable services in the cause
of geographical discovery and humanity, are
acknowledged and justly appreciated by all
civilized nations; for they have had for their
special object the welfare and advancement of
mankind.

“Understanding that your sojourn in England
is necessarily brief, the Society is obliged to
refrain from tendering at present any other
mark of their sincere esteem than that of nam-
ing you an honorary member of their body;
and, in doing so, they would beg to offer their
heartfelt wishes for your continued health and
happiness.

p.hi:
“By Order of the Committee,
“JULIUS LE SOUEF, Secretary.

body.p:
Baron von Humboldt returned the
following answer:—

“Monsieur,—Dans la vie agitée que nous
menons pendant le trop court sejour de mon
Souverain en Angleterre, il ne me reste que le
regret de ne pas avoir un moment de libre pour
exprimer personellement au comité de l’illustre
‘Colonial Society’ la vive reconnaissance dont
je me sens pénétré. Je vous supplie, Monsieur,
de vouloir bien être l’interprete de mes senti-
mens respectueux. Rien ne pourrait etre plus
flatteur pour mol que l’intéret que mes faibles
efforts ont pu inspirer à une réunion dont les
travaux tendent à un but si noble et si bien-
faisant pour l’humanité.
